title: bojo-and-the-seventy-two-virgins-a-toe-curling-tale-and-cashing-in-on-rail-delays
story: The new Caledonian sleeper service between Scotland and London has double beds, plush seats and everything you need for a prolonged stay. Fortunately, because that is what happened during the week when it broke down, and not for the first time, and punters were eventually turfed out at Stafford and spent the rest of the -mile trip on buses to Glasgow and Edinburgh. One unfortunate passenger tweeted that she felt like prisoner in an internment camp, which is no surprise because the Caledonian is run by Serco, which manages six prisons, including HMP Kilmarnock.Passengers were promised a full refund, although yoursquod think from the experience they deserved a bit more. Under this crazed rail system Network Rail, which owns the track, pays out to the private rail companies for delays, payments which are not designed to cover passenger refund claims but, ldquoto hold operators financially neutral to the long-term revenue impact, in the industry gobbledegook. Compensation for punters is ldquodetermined entirely by train operators.Which means, in practice that, although all those with hands in the till are coy about the exact sums, the operators make in excess of pound million a year more than they pay back to passengers, who get roughly p of every pound handed out to Brian Souter and Ann Gloag of Stagecoach and Rupert Soames of Serco.Ron McKay: Whos funding who in the race to No , Swede and sour, tapping the market and World Cup goalUBER THE TOPFrom the season after next the top French football league will be renamed Ligue  Uber Eats, after a euro million sponsorship deal. In each game the ball will be brought on to the field by an Uber delivery driver. I understand that the SPL are currently in negotiation with Uber for a similar deal for our Premiership after the current one with Ladbrokes ends in . The dference to France is that here the ball will be deep fried.FINGER AND THUMB KEEP MOVINGI am suffering from Adermatoglyphia. No, I didnrsquot know what it was either until a couple of days ago. I stumbled on it when my laptop refused to recognise me. Irsquom used to this from people Irsquove known for decades but this was a real shocker. Bear with me, Irsquom getting to the point, although itrsquos slow as Irsquom still suffering from post-digital stress disorder, PDSD.It started when I dug my fingers in the soil, as you do around this time of year getting back to nature, or vainly planting stuff you know is destined to die. My right index finger became badly infected, swelled up like a bursting banana and, to cut the tale of my travails short, I ended up in hospital for a couple of days.Jump cut to the computer episode. Itrsquos activated, like many of those modern devices, with a fingerprint. But it stubbornly wouldnrsquot come on. Which is when I discovered that, as all the skin on my finger had come off , there was now no fingerprint. Which is when I discovered this rare condition.In old movies criminals used to give their fingers acid baths to remove fingerprints, which always seemed both painful and counter-intuitive to me when they could simply nip out to BQ and get a pair of gloves .Anyway, no lasting harm, Irsquom told it will grow back, but in the meantime I obviously wonrsquot be able to visit the States ndash which I had no intention of doing anyway, other than hooded and in chains ndash because they take your fingerprints as you go in and, I learn from my sufferers group, they turn you backyou canrsquot provide a full set.A DIGITAL STORYI donrsquot know what they do about people with missing digits at US Homeland Security. Probably tag the person. Or saw the other ones off. But in Canada they preserve them and put them in your drink ndash and itrsquos not to ensure that other boozers donrsquot nick it. In Glasgow in the old days we used to spit in our pints as insurance before going to the toilet, but this is at another level entirely.In the Downtown Hotel in Dawson City in the Yukon they serve a Sourtoe Cocktail in which floats a mummied toe. To join the club ndash and why on earth would you  ndash the toe has to touch your lips as you down the shot whiskey. So I guess the toe-stbeforehand isnrsquot ldquoDown the hatch!.People have been preserving their digits and mailing them to the hotel. The latest to do so is British endurance athlete Nick Grfiths who lost three toes last year competing in the Yukon Arctic Race, the worldrsquos coldest ultra-marathon. He had seen an advert which said, ldquoHad frostbite  We want your toes. The big toe is the money shot Irsquom told.Apparently, Downtown now finds it pretty hard to come by toes because bounders keep nicking them from their drinks. I dread to think how they smuggle them out. The hotel now fines anyone who tries to steal one , around pound. They should be paying that to anyone who downs one.ANOTHER ONE BITES THE DUSTSo farewell then Esther McVey. Not many people knew you and you knew very little about almost anything. Apart from hair products of course. You wanted to cut pound billion from foreign aid, more than half of the budget, and you cited as your example of how money was being squandered citing airports where the ldquorunways were in the wrong direction and couldnrsquot be used. Where was this  ldquoIts in one of the... err... err... continents abroad.Most continents are. It was actually on Saint Helena in the far Atlantic Ocean, on what is a British Overseas Territory, and of the pound million cost not one thin halfpenny came from the aid budget. The island is where Napoleon Bonaparte died. Along with Esther McVaguersquos dream.VIRGIN ON THE RIDICULOUSI met Boris Johnson once in the Green Room of a TV studio. He was charming and funny in private as you might have expected, although I find his public views anathema. It was about that time that I had to read for review, speed read, what is his first and I think only novel, Seventy Two Virgins. The title comes from the number of young women a Muslim martyr is supposed to be given in Paradise. That would make for a tiring afternoon.It was a bit of a rompabout a group of Muslim terrorists invading the Parliament with, as I recall, one suicide bomberrsquos head flying off ldquoas though kicked by Jonny Wilkinson. And there was sex, likening that between a young Muslim man and an emancipated white woman as the cultural tectonic grinding between East and West. I donrsquot think it was nominated for the Bad Sex Awards either.The hero was a bicycling young Tory MP, apparently a bit of a buffoon but with a keen intellect, classical education of course, and an assistant named Cameron. I wonder where these characters came from

title: hiding-sectarianism-statistics-makes-football-fans-less-safe
story: Sitting before the Board of the Scottish Police Authority last February, Deputy Chief Constable Will Kerr said that the number of sectarian incidents and disorder at football appeared to be increasing, but he couldnrsquot confirm that because it was ldquohard to quanty.However in a new twist, it turns out that there is, in theory, two yearsrsquo worth of data and details on unacceptable behaviour at Scottish football. But the public, Parliament and campaigners are not allowed to see it.Research by the Scottish Liberal Democrats, in collaboration with anti-sectarianism charity Nil by Mouth, has revealed that this data is in fact being recorded and monitored. It is gathered by the Scottish Professional Football League , and shared with the government and the police. This arrangement, however, is subject to one important caveat ndash government and the police are sworn to secrecy.Establishing this much has been like navigating a maze.Months ago I asked the Justice Secretary about comments made by Kilmarnock manager, and now Scotland boss, Steve Clarke, who was taunted by sectarian slurs while standing on the touchline at a game. Reflecting on the abuse, he rightly branded it the stuff of the "Dark Ages". Upsettingly, he also said he was pleased Cha had taken him away from Scotland so his children and grandchildren didnrsquot have to grow up under the same cloud.His assessment was as frank as it was uncomfortable, and a moment of shame for both the game and our country. But we donrsquot know whether the incident that prompted it is contained in the SPFLrsquos secret database. The same goes for every other incident that has occurred up and down the country over the last two seasons, whether it is sectarian chanting, chair throwing, fireworks, assaults or abuse.Is sectarianism on the rise  Has it got worse this season  Is it only a minority of fans acting this way  The answer is we donrsquot know, because up until now the impression was given no one had the numbers.Professor Duncan Morrow is a world-renowned expert on sectarianism, hate crime and community cohesion. He was twice commissioned by the Scottish Government to delve into the problems in Scottish football and society more widely, and he concluded by recommending that incidents should be monitored and regularly published. This would help tackle sectarianism by boosting transparency and laying the groundwork for informed public debate. Nothing there to argue with ndash or so yoursquod imagine.But what resulted was a pathetic compromise. Despite Professor Morrowrsquos original ambition being openness, informed debate is only allowed to happen behind closed doors at SPFL, government and police headquarters. Instead of encouraging debate, they have muted it.This is a problem on a number of levels. The most fundamental is that we need baseline figureswersquore really going to measure progress. Banning this information from every seeing the light of day means football fans are less safe.As DCC Kerr rightly said in that same February meeting, we cannot let this become normal. Hateful chants, violence and sectarianism ruin the game for everyone . It means the vast majority of respectful fans get a bad name and in time could miss out on the chance to watch their teams because others think they can get away with unacceptable behaviour.Itrsquos absolutely scandalous that the Scottish Government are playing the puppet for the football authorities. It appears that they have used their cooperation as leverage. Ministers seem to have signed up to some sort of gagging deal. The Scottish Government now says that releasing the statistics they have been given could cause them to be cut off. It apparently wouldnrsquot be in the public interest to disclose the information. No competent administration could weave themselves into such a mess.Ministers need to step up and explain this to Scottish fans. Who signed away their silence and what exactly does this database show Liam McArthur is the justice spokesperson for the Scottish Liberal Democrats

title: scottish-government-seeks-views-on-legislation-to-tackle-human-trafficking
story: The Scottish Government proposes councils, health boards, the Scottish Ambulance Service, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, the Scottish Prison Service and Marine Scotland are among organisations to which new legislation will apply.It is hoped details collected through a duty to noty will provide a more accurate picture of the extent of human trafficking in Scotland, enabling more targeted enforcement and support.The Human Trafficking and ExploitationAct  came into force in November  and the Scottish Government is now seeking views on which organisations to include in the duty to noty.The information to be included in notications and who it should be passed on to by police is also under question ndash with proposals including all the the organisations subject to the rule as well as the National Crime Agency, Home Office and Interpol, among others.Border Force at Glasgow Airport piloted the project and made  referrals to the National Human Trafficking Unit in the nine months from September .Just been in a Police Scotland Serious Organised Crime awareness session, covering amongst other things human trafficking and modern slavery. You can buy a slave in the UK for pound. OCGs donrsquot care about people because le is cheap!mdash Sand##zwj##June , Launching the consultation, Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf said: ldquoHuman trafficking is a hidden and often complex crime meaning the true scale of the problem is unknown.ldquoVictims may be reluctant to acknowledge their own situation for reasons including fear of their traffickers, distrust in the authorities and a lack of awareness that there are agencies that can support them to safety and recovery.ldquoThese plans will create a statutory duty on Scottish public authorities to ensure that the information obtained by Police Scotland is publicly available.ldquoThis intelligence will ultimately help us to protect and support more vulnerable people.Police Scotland Assistant Chief Constable Gillian MacDonald said: ldquoThe introduction of a lsquoduty to notyrsquo is a positive step which will help us work with other public services to further develop our collective approach to protecting survivors.ldquoIt will also assist in helping victims to escape the clutches of traffickers, as we work to make Scotland a hostile environment for this type of inhumane criminality.NHS Scotland chief executive Malcolm Wright stressed the role health board staff could play in identying trafficking victims.He said: ldquoAll clinical and non-clinical staff across the NHS in Scotland can play a pivotal role in identying potential victims of human trafficking and exploitation that may otherwise go unnoticed or remain invisible.The consultation will close on September .

title: hundreds-of-council-workers-back-industrial-action
story: More than  construction and environmental department staff at Dundee City Council will take the step of industrial action following two ballots.Two weeks of strike action and an overtime ban will begin on July , with more strikes taking place every Monday and Tuesday afterwards until further notice, according to Unite.Members voted % in favour of the move on a % turnout ndash with hundreds more members to be balloted in the parks, leisure and culture and housing departments of the council.The union says the new policy from February enables the local authority to impose compulsory redundancies, limit flexible retirement and reduce pay protection for staff moved to lower grade posts.George Ramsay, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoThis is an emphatic result for strike action from Unite members who are determined to oppose the imposition of changes to their contracts.ldquoDundee City Councilrsquos new policy not only shamefully opens the door for workers to be made redundant but potentially at a reduced cost to the council.ldquoThis is the legal reality of the changes and no-one should underestimate the impact that this may have on job security and the protections currently available to workers.ldquoThe council has made a grave mistake in believing that they can behave like the worst of employers by failing to consult on these changes, and then they have the audacity to invite us back to lsquonegotiatersquo some concessions from them.ldquoUnite has an offer of our own for the council, which is reverse these imposed changes or face rolling industrial action.ldquoWe hope the public understand that this dispute has been solely created by the council but it is one which Unite will finish by winning.A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: ldquoWe continue to be proactive in our efforts to reach a way forward which will avoid the need for industrial action and will keep the channels of communication open with the trade unions and our workforce.ldquoThis policy is not about compulsory redundancies, nor is it about any changes to staff contracts. Our commitment to avoiding compulsory job losses is as strong as ever.ldquoInstead it is about allowing the council to change, modernise and redesign services to meet citizensrsquo future needs and deal with financial challenges.ldquoThose challenges have been signicant ndash we have been required to make savings of over pound million since  ndash and look likely to continue.ldquoStaff and their trade union representatives have a vital role to play in shaping the necessary changes.ldquoWe have offered a way forward and we continue to be willing to listen and engage with constructive proposals from the trade unions.

title: tories-decline-to-sign-cross-party-letter-urging-free-tv-licences-for-over-75s
story: The letter, organised by Labour, criticises plans to move from all over-s being given a free licence to means-testing from next year.ldquoCutting access to the free TV licence will be cutting many pensioners off from their main connection to wider society, the letter states.ldquoMillions of elderly and isolated people ndash hundreds of thousands here in Scotland ndash will suffer because of this cut.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Scottish Green co-convener Patrick Harvie all signed the letter.Conservative leader Ruth Davidson was asked to sign but declined, and the party said she has already made her position clear that free TV licences for over-s should be protected.Mr Leonard said: ldquoIt is telling that we have cross-party support for this intervention to keep free TV licences with the sole exception of Ruth Davidson and the Tories. Scotlandrsquos pensioners will not forget.He added: ldquoThe Tories have broken their promise to pensioners, and they must reverse the decision to scrap free TV licences now.SNP leader Ms Sturgeon added: ldquoWe vehemently oppose the decision that the BBC has been forced to take because of the cynical actions of the Tory Government.ldquoThe UK Government should not be shting the burden of their welfare cuts onto the BBC ndash with the costs being met out of pensionersrsquo pockets.Funding the free licences, which have been available to all over-s for nearly two decades, is due to be transferred from the UK Government to the BBC next year.The BBC has said free licences will be means-tested under a new scheme which aims to protect programming while dealing with the extra funding burden.Free licences will be restricted to over-s who claim Pension Credit from June  .BREAKING: @RuthDavidsonMSP backs @GMB campaign to make BBC reverse its decision to remove free TV licence fee for pensioners over .mdash Piers MorganJune , A Scottish Conservative spokesman said: ldquoRuth has already made her position on this matter known ndash both privately to senior colleagues in the UK Government ndash and publicly when asked during a TV interview this week.ldquoThe Scottish Conservatives strongly believe that TV licences for the over-s should be protected.ldquoWe believe the BBC have taken the wrong decision and will continue to argue this position.

title: joanna-blythman-the-food-has-lots-going-for-it-but-it-needs-to-put-taste-before-appearance
story: Same story as usual: dishes come in random order, at the whim of the kitchen. This is becoming a convention in small plates restaurants. Increasingly it irks me. You end up eating, say, cold cucumber after hot meat, a system that suits the kitchen, not the diner. We toy with a ldquosnack of salt cod mousse. It looks like a soft, cloud shaped meringue. Commendably, its salt has been restrained, but it needs something to deliver it from blandness. Lemon olive oil, or black pepper, maybe  The visual high point is its dehydrated cod skin, which has a popcorn-like texture with pretty silver and gold-glinting scales that taste only ever so slightly fishy.Pace is uneven. The salt cod comes quickly, therersquos a long gap, and then three dishes arrive back-to-back. This isnrsquot relaxing. They vie with each other and set up the dilemma of which to taste first. We bite into the crustily fried gnocchi, which do look lovely in a foamy green wild garlic espuma, but theyrsquore just a bit gluey in the centre. Salsy  Done three ways: roasted, pickled, pureacuteed  Canrsquot say no to that. The vegetable looks like a million dollars and the cooking is on point: a little crunchy, yet not losing that seductive silkiness. Blobs of blackgarlic add a visually pleasing contrast to the silver spears, and pack a welcome fruity, chocolate-like punch. This dish is meant to involve whey, a currently fashionable ingredient, although I canrsquot detect it. Descriptions are cryptic. ldquoAsparagus, duck egg, dashi consists of green spears, which are excessively salty, presumably from the dashiis accompanied by two puddles, one green , the other custard-coloured and reminiscent of over-vinegary mayonnaise. This is the egg, I assume.:Maybe not Nicorsquos finest hour ndash Six By Nico, Glasgow: Restaurant review by Ron MackennaSonder has a knack for colourful jumbles of unusual ingredient combinations. Our plate of white braised squid, bright orange burnt carrot pureacutee, and claret-hued radicchio is head-turning enough to make a magazine cover. In flavour terms though, it doesnrsquot hang together. The radicchio introduces a burnt, bitterness that makes the squid seem insipid.Melting beef short rib and bone marrow, topped with soft, slight vinegary shallots and mustard seed, flanked by a sateen caullower pureacutee, crispy cavalo nero, all sitting in a rich, clear gravy, hit a satisfaction point other dishes havenrsquot reached. They had flavours of watercolour intensity I prefer the culinary equivalent of oil paints.We ignore the enigmatically, some might say pretentiously named ldquostrawberries, cereal milk, Szechuan dessert for one that reads ldquolemon, white chocolate, saffron, polenta. We getdehydrated polenta cake that is actually engagingly edible, pungent with saffron. It could do with more of its curdy lemon gel to act as a foil for the thin shards of broken meringue, but the amiably crunchy cake element pleases the palate. ldquoChocolate, mint, caramel is a truncated description of what turns out to be a well-made chocolate mousse, served with a glorious fresh mint ice cream, and emerald green mint gel, set on mildly salty chocolate rubble.Sonder, although its food has lots going for it, has yet to rival EFS and Condita, butit put taste before appearance more, it might yet do so.Sonder, - S Clerk St, Edinburgh   Food:  Atmosphere:  Service:  Value for money:

title: what-men-can-learn-from-womens-football
story: The Americans celebrated each goal joyously, as was their right. But, as ever on social media, there were many who eagerly called them out for an alleged lack of class, for rubbing the Thai players noses in their grim misfortune - a misfortune, moreover, that was being watched by a television audience of countless millions.But others leapt to the Americans defence. Why on earth shouldnt they have the right to celebrate their superior skills  And, some asked, would the same criticism have been levelled at male players The issue was brilliantly addressed by Lindsay Gibbs, who covers sports on the progressive US news site, Think Progress.She wrote: "The lopsided score launched a litany of conversations ... about sportsmanship, excessive celebrations, sexism, equal pay, and the lack of investment in womenrsquos soccer globally. Itrsquos clear that this USWNT performance mdash which was led by a World Cup record five goals by Alex Morgan mdash has gotten under peoplersquos skin."But rather than trying to debate our way around the discomfort, perhaps it would be best to stew in it for a minute. Because the discomfort might just be the point."It should make us uncomfortable, she said, that the inequities in womenrsquos soccer "are so massive, that itrsquos not yet possible to have the field of a -team World Cup be competitive from top to bottom. It should make us queasy that many soccer federations donrsquot even convene training camps for women athletes, let alone arrange official friendly matches against quality opponents to enable those teams to build their ranking and develop their homegrown talent."It should "turn our stomachs" that Team USA, the most successful womenrsquos soccer team in the world, is still having to fight for equal pay. The players are currently suing U.S. Soccer for gender discrimination.Gibbs also pointed out that the female players decided to take on such a big-time lawsuit right before the biggest tournament of their lives "because they knew that this is the only time in the next four years that they will receive this much attention. They need every ounce of leverage that they can muster, since U.S. Soccer is so hesitant to endorse equality. The U.S. women believe they must win the tournament to advance this larger cause. Because of that self-imposed burden, every match, every goal at the  Womenrsquos World Cup, takes on a heightened signicance."Referring to the celebrations that greeted all of the  goals, Gibbs made this telling observation: "Theres also something refreshing about seeing womenrsquos emotions in such a pure, unfiltered state, and seeing how much every single goal meant to these women, who have dedicated their lives to this sport, and still have to fight for so much every time they take the field."At the end of the game, some US players, including Carli Lloyd, made a point of commiserating with the hapless Thai goalkeeper, Sukanya Chor Charoenying, on what was probably one of the worst nights of her le.And in another touching moment, Alex Morgan sought out, in front of the cameras, the Thailand forward, Miranda Nild, to console her. Nild was born in Northern Calornia and, like Morgan, played soccer while at the University of Calornia, Berkeley.The debate quickly widened. Is there anything that the mens game could learn from the womens game, despite the vast inequality in funding and wages Many pointed to the womens sportsmanship, to their respect for the match referees, for their general lack of prima donna behaviour.ldquoThere are absolutely things that the menrsquos game can learn from the World Cup," Vivienne MacLaren, chair of Scottish Womens Football, said on Friday. "I think the biggest thing is the behaviour of the players on the pitch. Diving, play-acting, etcetera are very uncommon within the girlsrsquo and womenrsquos game. On the whole, most players are very honest and menrsquos football could certainly learn from this.ldquoWhile I appreciate itrsquos not easy in the menrsquos game, the family-friendly atmosphere at womenrsquos gamesrsquo is a huge plus. Most games arenrsquot segregated and you find fans of both teams can sit together and enjoy the match. Itrsquos maybe not something that can be lsquolearnedrsquo but I certainly believe itrsquos something to be aspired to.ldquoFinally, I also think there is an unmatched pride that these women have playing for their country," she adds."Knowing the Scotland players and the set-up, there isnrsquot one player who wouldnrsquot do anything to pull on that shirt. I think most of the menrsquos squad are the same but not all of them. Maybe that comes from the incredible amount of money players receive from their clubs, which is the complete opposite within the womenrsquos game at the present time.On social media, to no great surprise, the womens World Cup has attracted criticism - much of it well-meaning, but large proportions of it sexist - but many men have voiced their support."Dference between men and womens football...women get up when they fall get fouled unless they are genuinely hurt and not roll around, they dont fall to the ground so easy, they complain less to the refs, they get on and play," noted one Twitter user. "Just wished more men had the same attitude as the women, get up and get on with it."Im not saying women dont do it," he added, "in general men do it more, women try to play fairly where as the men will try to play dirty and get away with things more than the women do. Womans football doesnt get the credit it deserves, Im only on about the style of play thats it cause I love mens football too. The womens game Ive watched they are always trying to get back up when they can or stay on their feet but the men will go down at any opportunity.""I tell you something. Mens football could learn a thing or two from the womans game," tweeted aArsenal fan. "No rolling around in the floor faking injuries, not surrounding the ref screaming and shouting." A female Twitter user responded: "Yes!! Way too much of those two things in the mens game! Also, refreshing to see some fast-paced football "."Do all these blokes ripping into the quality of the Womenrsquos World Cup realise the women playing are miles better than any of them  " challenged yet another man on Twitter.Another made the point: "Mensfootball relies on speed and strength to a greater extent than the womens game. If you actually watch the games, youll see a greater use of skillssuch as running off the ball into danger areas, reverse passing, better ball-trapping."As Lindsay Gibbs concluded her article on Think Progress: "These women are not at the World Cup to instill a sense of comfort in those for whom nothing is at stake theyrsquore there to become champions, provoke change, and convince people to care about womenrsquos soccer. Therersquos a long way to go in this tournament, but based upon how quickly theyrsquove provoked discussion, theyrsquore right on target.THE womens World Cup, which is being staged in France, has already proved to be an inspiration - on and off the pitch.Michelle Owen, the Sky football reporter presenter, tweeted enthusiastically: "A womenrsquos World Cup on prime time TV. This would never have happened when we were kids, this is amazing. Please let this grow the womenrsquos game here, wersquove a long way to go but we are getting there!"One woman who responded to Owen wrote: "Its a start and may it continue to grow. I have a  year old daughter and this is another door opening for hershe wishes to play football etc. Negative comments are old-school Neanderthals end of."In the aftermath of the US teams -goal demolition of Thailand, Alex Scott, who was capped  times for England and is now is a regular pundit for BBC Sport and Sky Sports. tweeted: "When I was , I was trying to do things watching the mens World Cup, watching the original Ronaldo doing stepovers. Tomorrow people will be waking up, seeing Alex Morgan do a touch like that, and theyll say thats who I want to be like."Other followers of the game have even been inspired by the sight of an all-female BBC  discussing a particular match. "I feel quite emotional watching four women doing the half-time analysis," said one. "Ive waited my whole le for this."* Scotland play Argentina on Wednesday, kick-off pm.

title: how-the-prom-industry-is-cashing-in
story: In sumptuous, glittering cocktail dresses and gowns, sharp suits and the occasional kilt, hair glossed, gelled, curled or straightened, tans sprayed, nails done and eyebrows plucked, and, finally, amid a puff of hairspray and scent, school leavers across the land have been on the move.Scotlandrsquos prom season is in full swing, bringing months of preparation to a high-pitched squeal when the class of rsquo finally say "cheerio!" to  years or so of school le and a huge "hiya!" to college, university or work.For most parents for whom proms were things Sandy and Danny Zuko did in Grease and leaving school involved a quick "see ya" and a group hug, waving their teens off for a night of prom partying, has not come cheap.Indeed, with some splashing pound or more on their daughterrsquos dress ndash never mind shoes, make-up and accessories ndash it would probably have been cheaper to opt for a holiday in the sun or deposit on a second-hand car.But while few would grudge excited young people the opportunity to celebrate a milestone, concern is mounting over the pressure prom season may be placing on Scotlandrsquos less well-off families.And, according to Marion Davis, Head of Policy at One Parent Families Scotland, the time has come for the Scottish Government to look at ways of curbing the excess to ensure that teenagers in the grip of poverty are not frozen out of what has evolved into a new rite of passage.ldquoThere is concern among parents about the growing lsquoprom culturersquo in schools that might exclude young people from low-income families who cannot afford to take part, she says.ldquoYoung people have every right to have a lovely time celebrating, however, there is the question of expense and the pressure it may put on families who are already struggling.ldquoIn some areas in Scotland, half of children are growing up in poverty. Schools should go the extra mile to ensure that young people from these families do not miss out ndash or that their parents have to go without to keep up with better-off families.Young people who are excluded from the chance to participate in the same activities as their friends and counterparts ndash such as the school prom ndash can have a negative impact on health and wellbeing, she adds.ldquoThe Scottish Government should be asked to look at this issue ndash to research and assess the impact of this exceptional extra cost.ldquoEducation authorities should undertake impact assessments on existing policies and associated practices to assess the impact on low-income families.ldquoSchools should be supported to have guidelines for parents at the start of prom arrangements to make sure the events are as inclusive as possible.In Wales, where childhood poverty is rising, minister of education, Kirsty Williams was last week warned of a ldquocompetition between parents and urged to launch research into the impact lsquoprom feverrsquo can have on poorer families.Certainly, the scale and number of high school proms across the entire UK have erupted. Prom dresses are now said to cost an average of pound ndash plus around twice that for accessories and beauty treatments. Nationwide, around pound million is spent in the UK each year on prom-related outfits, styling and extras like hire cars.Lesley Christie of bespoke bridal and eveningwear specialist Christie Couture in Clarkston says therersquos been a definite increase in prom spending. ldquoYou have hundreds of girls all looking at dresses at the same time, so their parents will pay more to find them something unique.ldquoMy most expensive dress is pound, but itrsquos not unusual for people to spend pound to pound. There are people who have spent up to pound on a prom dress.ldquoBut at the same time, plenty go to TK Maxx and pick up a dress for a fraction of the cost.ldquoTo be honest, thatrsquos almost nicer - therersquos almost a stereotypical prom look, and all the girls can end up looking the same.She has sympathy with parents who, caught in the emotion of seeing children morph into young men and women, can easily find themselves forking out over the odds.And she is braced for what may be ahead with her own daughter, Cameron, , who is currently looking forward to Gfnock Primaryrsquos P end of term ceilidh. ldquoItrsquos not called a prom, she adds. ldquoBecause itrsquos a ceilidh therersquos a feeling that itrsquos not about getting dressed to excess.ldquoShersquoll wear white plimsols and white knee socks and an lsquoAlice in Wonderlandrsquo dress from Monsoon.ldquoIrsquom not saying she wonrsquot be in full prom mode when she leaves high school, but right now shersquos a child.Yet there is evidence that some primary school end of term discos have evolved into red carpet parties, with -year-old girls in off-the-shoulder cocktail frocks, full makeup and tottering on towering heels.It certainly doesnrsquot get more extreme than the incident in , when East Renfrewshire Council rejected a request to land a helicopter in the grounds of Mearns Primary in Newton Mearns.At Exquisite Limousines in Dunfermline, the fleet of four Calornian built stretch limos are currently polished to perfection, tinted windows and mirrored ceiling streak-free, interior disco lights and sound system tested and ready for the next prom run.In the past they would ferry groomed high school leavers to local hotels, these days itrsquos more likely to be giggling gangs of Ps. ldquoTherersquos been a vast reduction in the amount of high school prom bookings, says a spokesman. ldquoNow, itrsquos more primary school kids. Itrsquos just % high school and % primary school proms.But for older teens, therersquos no denying the excitement of the high school prom. Last week Katie Hamilton, , and friends from Douglas Academy were among the countless Scottish S and S pupils who dressed to the nines and partied away their final school hours.ldquoThere were girls wearing dresses that cost pound to pound, she says. ldquoI tried to find a dress for under pound but there just wasnrsquot anything that I wanted. I spent around pound, but it was the perfect dress.ldquoI did my own nails, make-up and tan - Irsquom not spending pound on my make up when I can just do it myself.The prom at Ingliston Country Club and Hotel cost pound a head. For parents who waved their children off, the evening perfectly captured that fleeting moment between childhood, school stresses and the edge of adulthood.ldquoI canrsquot deny it wasnrsquot emotional, says Jan Mackay, whose son, Ciaran, waited in a huge queue of teenagers at Slaters to pick his suit for the Douglas Academy prom.ldquoThe kids were dead excited and itrsquos at that funny point where theyrsquore no longer schoolkids and on the brink of moving on but not quite there yet.ldquoIt feels like the end of something big and, of course, therersquos a degree of hysteria.But not all prom nights have to be crushingly expensive. In Edinburghrsquos plush five-star Balmoral Hotel, -year-old Jayda Puren and her best friend Eve Woehrling, , rolled up to the St Thomas of Aquinrsquos High School prom looking stunning in their second-hand dresses.ldquoWe decided a little while ago to stop buying new clothes to reduce our carbon footprint, says Jayda. ldquoThe most expensive thing was probably my dress, but that was only about pound or pound.Her class of rsquo paid pound a head for their night out, but Jayda would have been just as happy with something less lavish.ldquoI wouldrsquove been finesomeone did like a McDonalds run and we all just went off to a public hall to dance and have fun.ldquoNo one even knew what was in the food anyway, it was all so posh. One of my friends spent around pound on drinks alone, so yeah, ridiculous might be an understatement.Prom, she reckons, is a little over-hyped. ldquoThat doesnrsquot mean itrsquos not going to be fun to dress up and see your friends but I donrsquot think people get that itrsquos not all itrsquos chalked up to be, she adds.ldquoProm for me was just a gloried school disco.

title: scotlands-population-is-heading-east-and-away-from-the-countryside
story: A task force of Scottish Government ministers has been set to prepare policies to manage the countrys changing demographic, which are expected to see families leaving areas such as Inverclyde, Ayrshire, Argyll and the Western Isles for Edinburgh, Fe and the Lothians.It comes against a backdrop of a falling birthrate and an increasingly elderly population, which will see any future population growth driven my migration from overseas and the rest of the UK.The challenge will be to ensure those left behind still have access to decent public services and ing economies while ensuring no skills shortage appears as the labour pool recedes.:The forgotten battle of ScotlandThere will also be a focus on the dispersal of population across Scotland and how the economic benefits of future population growth are spread across all communities.According to official figures, the population of the Western Isles is expected to drop be more than , by , and by more than , in Inverclyde.Argyll and Bute, which covers a large part of the west coast, is predicted to lose , people in the same timeframe, as is North Ayrshire. Statisticians estimate a fall of the population will drop by  in North Ayrshire.However, the population of Midlothian is expected to swell by more than , in the coming decade, while East Lothian will see the numbers living within its borders increase by more than ,.Edinburgh is predicted to see a demographic boom, with an extra , souls coming to live and work in the city. Glasgow is one area in the west immune to the flight eastwards, with its population predicted to grow by , in the next seven years. It currently stands at around ,.Faisal Choudhry, Director of Scottish Research at estate agents Savills, said that the swing from west to east was being driven by the demand for affordable homes and a boom in the economy around Edinburgh.He said: "There have been a number of large-scale new build housing developments in Falkirk, Bathgate, Fe and across the Lothians and this is bringing people to the area."While there has been some work done in the West, it has been longer in coming and is not on the same scale."People are taking advantage of this, as well as the growth in the financial sector and the tech industry in Edinburgh.":New York bank closes in on new Glasgow siteHe added that a brain drain from rural areas and post-industrial towns such as Greenock had been apparent for some time, while people were also seeking lower house prices.Mr Choudhry said: "People ahve been priced out of Edinburgh and Glasgow and are moving out to the new builds in the surrounding areas."And they will always go where there are employment opportunities, a strong economy and good schools on offer."Earlier this week, official statistics showed that , babies were born in Scotland during the first quarter of , the second lowest figure since civil registration began in .Scotlandrsquos population of . million has been growing since the turn of the century, but only because of migration, largely from continental Europe.In , the latest year records area available for, deaths outstripped births by about ,, with the , births registered being the lowest since .: Dundee named best place to live in ScotlandCabinet Secretary for Tourism, Culture and External Affairs Fiona Hyslop said: ldquoWe need to grow our population to ensure we have sustainable, vibrant and resilient communities and drive improvements in inclusive growth. In doing so, it is also imperative that we maintain inward migration to help grow the economy.ldquoIt is welcome that people are living longer, though the continued availability of labour is essential to support our public services, boost our economy and address potential skills shortages in all sectors of the labour market.ldquoThe focus of this task group will be on identying the good work that is already underway across Government, intensying that work where needed as well as identying and addressing further opportunities for change.

title: fisheries-braced-for-invasion-of-pink-salmon
story: SCIENTISTS and fisheries bosses are braced for the arrival of hordes of alien salmon in Scottish rivers after an ldquoexplosive invasion of the fish in Scotland two years ago, possibly driven by climate change.Anglers have been put on alert to report sightings of pink or humpback salmon, which could harm native river le. Experts are on standby in case the fish are found to be carrying disease.If they arrive it is expected to be later this month or next. Anyone who catches one has been told to kill it and send it to fisheries managers. Anglers are also warned to look out for spawning fish, which could mean populations becoming established.Only a handful of humpback salmon, native to Pacic North America, were found in Scottish waters until . That year  of them were seen, with some spotted laying eggs in the Spey, Ness and Aberdeenshire Dee.The fish have a two-year le-cycle and come back from the sea in odd years, so scientists have been waiting until this year to seethe invasion happens again, andpink salmon have a breeding toehold here.If they get established scientists say they would be dficult to sht, and their nest-building could damage the rare lamprey.They are highly aggressive when defending nests, so could attack native fish, and could also possibly compete for food, and interfere with native salmon migration and the le cycle of very rare freshwater pearl mussels. Pink salmon die after spawning, and another concern is the of effect masses of dead fish on rivers.Chris Conroy, director of the Ness District Salmon Fishery board, filmed pink salmon spawning in  after anglers caught two in the River Ness.He said: ldquoWe have footage of them chasing trout, they are very territorial. They just shouldnrsquot be here.Writing in the Journal of Fish Biology, experts from Scottish Natural Heritage, Marine Scotland and Fisheries Management Scotland described the  invasion and set out concerns over Oncorhynchus gorbuscha ndash the scientic name for the fish.The authors ndash John Armstrong, Colin Bean, and Alan Wells ndash say the fish originate from stocks introduced to western Russia, which got into Norwegian rivers and then crossed the North Sea.They list just  pink salmon detected between  and  in Scotland, with the maximum in any year being five in , and just one in .They say: ldquoAgainst this sporadic appearance, the  reports represent an unusual and explosive invasion of O. gorbuscha to Scotland.ldquoA total of  ... were recorded across a broad range of riversNo explanation has been found for rsquos invasion, but the scientists say: ldquoOf greatest concern is that,progressive change in climate is a root cause, then invasions of O. gorbuscha to Scottish waters will probably continue. At this stage, however, the magnitude and frequency of such occurrence cannot be predicted.They believe a breeding population of pink salmon is unlikely as things stand, as they spawn early here and migrate to sea in the autumn when food is scarce, butthey begin spawning later in the year it might mean spring migration, boosting survival chances and the likelihood of the fish breeding here.Most deliberate introductions of the salmon have proven tricky, but the team says the introduction in western Russia was ldquovery successful: that could mean invaders in Scotland are genetically selected to be good invaders.The scientists say rooting out established pink would be dficult. Digging up nests was deemed ldquotoo resource intensive and risky, and netting them would damage other fish including native salmon.Chris Conroy added: ldquoIf their numbers build up and theyrsquore at the same feeding grounds at sea they could compete with our salmon for food. Itrsquos an unknown ndash theyrsquore not native and any non-native shouldnrsquot be here ... they could potentially be carrying disease. We donrsquot know what the risk is, so I class that as being of concern.Jo Long, senior conservation policy officer from the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency, said: ldquoOne bad year doesnrsquot indicate a trend of any kind, so the real focus is on gathering information and trying to assess whether this is a sign of things to come.ldquoWersquore much more organised this year to gather the information to help answer these questionsldquoWersquove got everyone on the alert in the angling community so we can get much better data and seethis is something we should be worried about.She added: ldquoTo date there have been no diseased fish of those that have been reported. If there were signs of diseases we would be looking at those fish in detail and wersquove got plans to do thatthat should happen.

title: 20th-anniversary-of-wifi-how-did-we-ever-live-without-it
story: Do you think you could live without wi  Thats a question my parents have posed to me many times throughout my le. Of course I could! How hard could it possibly be Apparently, pretty dficult.How people managed before wi existed is beyond me. It has completely revolutionised the way we live our lives ndash we are totally dependent on it. It has made everything we do so much faster and easier. As a result, we are becoming so much lazier. Itrsquos almost aswe donrsquot need to know stuff anymore. It has transformed the way we work and obtain information ndash making it a lot less dficult.Those who have been around since before wi-filove to talk of how they lived before it. Irsquove been told stories from back in the day, when you had to spend hours looking through booksyou needed to know something. Even finding the right book to look through took time.People often refer to the past as simpler times, but in reality, itrsquos the present that is simplying everything. Thanks to wi, whether on a phone or a laptop, every piece of information we could want or need is right in front of us within seconds. Google even tells you how long it took to get the results, which is never more than half a second. A world of information right at our fingertips ... itrsquos strange to think anyone knew anything before.Universities use wi for almost everything: lecture slides and notes are uploaded essays are researched, uploaded and grades ed online. Unlike with handing in a paper copy, "my Wi-Fi wasnrsquot working" is a much more robust excuse as to why your essay was a day late. Unlike telling them "I forgot" , a lecturer canrsquot prove that your wi wasnrsquot working. If you can hand in an essay at .pm when itrsquos due at midnight, therersquos so much room for procrastination. Wersquore becoming lazier because wi does everything for us: it hands in our essays, it does our research ... all while we lie in our bed with our jammies on. Therersquos very little that we actually need to do ourselves anymore.Friendships have been completely altered by wi. We donrsquot talk to people anymore. We check up on their lives through Facebook or Instagram. Before wi,it was someonersquos birthday yoursquod send them a card, give them a call or stop in at their house to say happy birthday. We donrsquot even need to remember when their birthdays are anymore ndash thatrsquos what Facebook is for. It reminds you whose birthday it is and when, even nudging you to wish them well.We can stay in touch with people all over the world, discover old friends we havenrsquot been in touch with for years. Before wi,your friend moved across the globe, what did you do  Maybe an occasional letter or a phone call, forgetting what they looked likeyou ever did see them again. Today, pull out your phone, do a quick search on Facebook and you can know every part of their le, in detail. We are more open to the world than was ever possible before wi.People can learn every detail of our le as and when it happens, but wersquove stopped actually talking to them because wersquove run out of things to say. Wi has, in a way, destroyed our friendships while at the same time making us feel like they are much stronger. Admittedly itrsquos a problem caused by the internet and social media ndash but itrsquos wi that facilitates it. If internet were the disease, wi would be patient zero.Donrsquot get me wrong, itrsquos amazing to know that your best friend from  years ago is now a successful ballet dancer in Wales, or that your cousin in America just graduated college. We can keep in touch with family and friends around the world, even when everyone is on dferent time zones. I canrsquot even begin to imagine how expensive it would be to FaceTimesomeone in Australiait werenrsquot for wi, or to message your friends when yoursquore in a foreign country. Wi enables connectionanywhere and everywhere.Not only has it changed the way we maintain our friendships, itrsquos also changed how they start. I distinctly remember my first day of university. A group of us were sitting in the foyer of our accommodation and instead of actually chatting and getting to know one another, we passed our phones around the group so we could follow each other on Instagram. We had probably exhausted all avenues of conversation by that point . Without wi we would have just sat in awkward silence. Or would we have been better at talking Thanks to wi, most friendships begin online. Before it,you met someone and didnrsquot get the number for their landlinethen that was it. You would probably never see them again. Itrsquos completely dferent now. You meet someone and one of the first things you do is whip out your phone and find a way of staying in touch ndash not that you ever do.People come in to your house and the first thing they ask is lsquoWhatrsquos the wi password rsquo But they shouldnrsquot be there to use the wi. How about we stop pulling out our phones every few minutes and actually have a conversation  Or is that too much to ask For people of my generation, we havenrsquot had a choice. Our society needs wi to , itrsquos a requirement in almost everything we do. Itrsquos part of our generation and will be a part of every generation to come. It may not be good for us, but there is no way we can live without it.A brief history of wi: Hollywood actress Hedy Lamarr invents and patents a technologythat isnrsquot revisited until decades later when it is discovered that it can be used for Wi-Fi.: University of Hawaii provides the first public demonstration of a wireless packet data network: Industry recognized standards established. Wi is trademarked and becoming a household name only % of British households have internet access.A common misconception is that the term wi is short for "wireless fidelity", however this is not the case. It is simply a trademarked phrase that means IEEE .x: The word lsquowirsquo is added to the dictionary: Wi in % of homes worldwide:  billionth wi-enabled device ships: % of British households have internet access: The  billionth wi device ships

title: aberdeenshire voluntary action celebrates volunteers week
story: Aberdeenshire Voluntary Actionhas celebrated the huge contribution volunteers make across Aberdeenshire communities.Volunteers’ Week, held from June  to , aims to celebrate and say thank you to volunteers across the UK for their contributions.Inverurie Day Centre volunteersIn Aberdeenshire’s towns, villages and rural areas volunteers help to provide many important, often vital, services, facilities and opportunities for local people of all ages.As the Third Sector Interface in Aberdeenshire, AVA provides support and guidance across the area to people who are interested in volunteering as well as organisations with volunteers. AVA is a one-stop-shop for all things volunteering and its Development Officers work right across theand breadth of Aberdeenshire.Keith Anderson, AVA Head of Development said: “Helping volunteering to happen is a key part of our work and an area that we all enjoy. We are always amazed at people’s generosity with their time and that willingness to be there for others makes such a dference.”During this year’s Volunteer Week AVA celebrated Margaret Murison for over  years of volunteering in Balmedie.Margaret was honoured as an outstanding volunteer in May with a presentation by AVA at The Friendship Club within Eigie House in Balmedie, where Margaret volunteers.Well-wishers, friends and family all wanted to be in on the surprise presentation for Margaret – but once word sneaked out the lounge was soon filled to capacity as everyone descended on Eigie House to see Margaret receive her award.The event was organised by Rosie Nicol from Belhelvie Community Trust, who spoke about her dedication to some special projects in the district, including The Beach Wheelchairs and The Sand Bothy. Margaret used to work in the bank for many years so generally gets asked to deal with many of the financial elements of the organisations she helps.She is also an invaluable source of expertise on family history locally, enjoys her garden and volunteering with the Church which is very close to her heart.AVA Development Officer, Lorna Sandison said: “I am delighted to be included in on-going and new projects in the Balmedie area as it is such a motivated and connected community where lessons can be learned as to how communities should indeed interact. Huge congratulations to Margaret who has contributed so much to the area – she is an inspiration to many”.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aaron Bisset impressed industry professionals at Glasgow performance"  Rothienorman actor signed by talent agency viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"AVA also celebrated the volunteers providing vital support services at Inverurie Day Centre.The centre is is available for older people, aged  or over and people with disabilities who enjoy social contact, but are less able to get out and about, or need support to manage day to day tasks.The Day Centre has a fantastic team of eight dedicated volunteers who supportDay Care Organisers Maggie McRitchie and Mo Ritchie to deliver activities for the service users throughout the day. AVA Development Officer, Meriem Kayoueche-Reeve organised a volunteer celebration in the run-up to Volunteers’ Week to say big thank you to the fantastic volunteers at the Day Centre. Of the eight volunteers at the Day Centre, three of them had been volunteering for over  years.Meriem presented a celebration cake and awarded each of the volunteers a certicate recognising their valued contribution to the Day Centre and the health and wellbeing of the service users.Meanwhile AVA also celebrated  National Trust volunteers at Crathes Castle.The volunteers who help at a iety of National Trust locations in the North East including Crathes Castle, Drum Castle, Mar Lodge Estate, Craigie Castle and Castle Fraser were invited to a ‘Thank You’ Tea Party celebration as part of this year’s Volunteers’ Week.Aileen said: “Volunteers are invaluable to so many charities and community organisations in Aberdeenshire, what an honour it is to celebrate those who give their time to their communities.”

title: beef event one of the best yet
story: Early morning rain failed to deter farmers from attending the Scottish Beef Association#s Scotland#s Beef Event  held last month on a leading Aberdeenshire beef farm.Around , people streamed into North Bethelnie Farm, near Oldmeldrum, on Thursday, May .Rural Economy Cabinet Secretary, Fergus Ewing, speaking at the opening ceremony“It was a very successful day and generally recognised as one of the best of the biennial beef events the SBA has organised over the years,” said SBA vice-chairman, David Barron, who chaired the organising committee.“The  trade stands reported good business and the extensive technical demonstration area was thronged throughout the day with farmers keen to pick up all the latest technology for the beef industry.”Mr Barron was full of praise for the host farmers, Robbie and Barbara Milne, and their son, James, who put on a great show.One of the highlights of the day was the tour of the  acre all-grass farm – with no fewer than  tractors and trailers at the ready to avoid queuing – which took visitors right to the top of the hill, where they were treated to an ice-cream from neighbouring farmers, Mackie’s, while enjoying magnicent views of the Aberdeenshire countryside looking up to Bennachie.Beef farmers – like all farmers and indeed the whole of industry – are facing an uncertain future as the debacle and stalemate of the Brexit negotiations continues.The only thing farmers can do is to make sure they are operating as efficiently and productively as possible so they are in a strong position to cope with whatever hits them in the future – in or out of Europe – and they had plenty of pointers at the Beef Event which more than lived up to its theme - Breeding, Feeding, Succeeding.Rural Economy Cabinet Secretary, Fergus Ewing, who in giving the official opening address, reiterated his support for the beef industry and determination to reverse the continuing decline in the national beef herd.But saying is not doing although, in fairness to Mr Ewing, he dropped more than a broad hint that the Scottish Government is looking at an emergency support package for the beef sector. This could take the form of increased headage payments under the existing beef calf support scheme.The SBA, along with NFU Scotland and other industry stakeholders, have been pressing Mr Ewing on the issue and SBA chairman, Neil McCorkindale, was hoping for an announcement by the Cabinet Secretary at the event.This didn’t materialise but Mr Ewing indicated he was sympathetic to the plea and accepted the argument that headage payments would be a more effective approach than area based support which would simply encourage inertia in the industry.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Owners Jonny and Ali Aspden"  Popular Ellon coffee shop extends opening hoursviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aby Wilson, Stuart Wood, Elaine Lownds, George Laing, and Director Nicola Alexander of Bethan Customs Consultancy"  Oldmeldrum start-up doubles team viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: explorer scouts raise over 1k at fun dog show event
story: The Daviot and Oldmeldrum Explorer Scouts kicked off fundraising for their second trip to volunteer at a school in Uganda at the weekend.The group held their annual Fun Dog Show in Oldmeldrum on Sunday, June .The event raised around £,.At the Fun Dog Show there was a choice of ten classes and over  dogs took part.The DOM Explorer Scouts ran a tea and cake tent whilst a number of local pet-related businesses had stalls.The Scratch Club from Inverurie ran Flyball demonstations and also let people try with their own dogs.The DOM Explorer Scouts were supported by a number of local businesses who sponsored the event.They hope to hold the next Fun Dog Show on Sunday, June  .In July  the DOM Explorer Scouts visited Ruhanga in SW Uganda to help finish building a School  Scout Hall that they had funded. In July  a new group of DOM Explorer Scouts plan to go again, this time to build a dormitory for the boarding children at the school.In rural Uganda, boarding during P gives the pupils the best opportunity to pass their national exams – for most, the highest level of education they will reach.Many of the children live in extreme poverty at least an hour’s walk away from school.Boarding gives them the chance to gain the extra tuition needed in an environment where they are well-cared for and better fed than their own families can afford at home.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Business advisory director Emma Waterman"  Firm grows in Inverurie as local economy goes digital on taxviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"BrewDog Inverurie"  Licence for Inverurie BrewDog bar despite objections viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"The school is supported by UK charity Uganda Lodge Community Projects who the DOM Explorer Scouts have a close relationship with.The DOM Explorer Scouts will need to raise approximately £, for this project.This will cover the build project and contribute to the travel and accommodation costs for the trip.For more information about the Daviot and Oldmeldrum Explorer Scouts and their upcoming trip to Uganda or to donate towards the travel costs please see the ‘Daviot Oldmeldrum Explorers’ page on Facebook.

title: further industrial action dates announced for aberdeen airport
story: The action will take place on Thursday  and Friday  June, both commencing at am until am.Aberdeen Airport is part of AGS Airports Limited group, which also owns Glasgow where a series of industrial stoppages are taking pace over the coming days. The dispute centres on a pay claim and AGS closing the defined benefit pension scheme. This broke an Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration ServiceAgreement made in  to keep the scheme open to existing members, despite Aberdeen Airport increasing after tax profits from £. million in  to £. million in .Unite can confirm that Aberdeen Airport management yesterday made a repackaged  per cent pay offer for , which is materially the same as the one tabled in negotiations through Acas in April. Critically, AGS in the latest approach restated their unwillingness to discuss or reopen the consultation on closing the pension scheme, which sets unacceptable preconditions for any further negotiations with Unite. Unite members at Aberdeen Airport have previously taken two twelve hour stoppages on  and  June at exactly the same time action was undertaken at Glasgow Airport. In April, Unite members at Aberdeen Airport supported strike action by . per cent on a . per cent turnout over the pay claim and the proposals to close the final salary pension scheme.Shauna Wright, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoUnite members will now undertake two further days of industrial action at Aberdeen Airport following this latest pitul attempt to ide and conquer by AGS. We want the public to understand that our members do not take this action lightly. But, AGS have repeatedly set preconditions to any negotiations by stating they will not reopen the consultation on the pension scheme, which breaks our Acas agreement with them.ldquoUnite members remain strong and resolute, and they are determined to stand united with their fellow members in Glasgow who are facing the same attack on their pay and pension scheme by AGS. For the record, Unite wants to reaffirm that we are always open to meaningful negotiations to seek a remedy to this dispute at any time, any place and under any auspices. The ball is in AGSrsquo court.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"NHS Grampian"  Mobile Breast Screening Service to begin in InverurieviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"J G Ross accept their Scottish Baker of the Year accolades"  Inverurie baker tastes success in national competition viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie baker tastes success in national competition
story: J G RossLtd of Inverurie did their customers proud at the weekend by taking home a top prize in the Scottish Baker of the Year   competition.The bakery was awarded a Regional Gold for its Macaroni Pie, a Regional Silver for its White Bread and a Special Gold for its Buttery.Cameron Ross of J G RossLtd said: “We are delighted and we have our customers to thank as it was their votes that got us here. Taking home such a prestigious prize is a huge honour and we cannot wait to share the news with our staff and customers alike.”Following the votes of over , bakery customers across Scotland and a rigorous day of blind judging by  of the industry’s top professionals, the winners were finally announced on Saturday, June  at a glittering awards dinner at the Crowne Plaza in Glasgow.“This competition is hugely popular, with thousands of everyday bakery shoppers voting for their favourite products,” said Head Judge, Robert Ross.“We received over , inidual product votes for goods baked by the best bakers in Scotland. J G RossLtd can be very proud to take home a prize in such a competitive field of brilliant products.”The Scottish Baker of the Year Competition, now in its th year, recognises Scotland’s best pies, scones, loaves, savoury items, morning rolls, cakes and biscuits. Business awards are also given to the best Café Bakery, Craft Bakery, Retail Bakery and Wholesale Bakery with one lucky baker being crowned Scottish Baker of the Year.Alasdair Smith of Scottish Bakers, who organise the competition said, “We are delighted to once again be giving Scottish bakers the chance to shine and showcase their fantastic products and it has given us great delight to present awards to each and every worthy winner.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Police appeal after thefts from Aberdeenshire properties viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: neighbours object to brewdog s inverurie pub hours
story: Neighbours of BrewDog#s newly-opened bar in Inverurie have raised objections to their formal premises licence.The brewery is seeking the green light to continue operating from am to midnight Sunday to Thursday and from am to am Friday and Saturday.It also wants to continue providing off-sales from am to pm Monday to Sunday.Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board will debate the application on Wednesday, June .It will hear from two residents who have questioned the need for the ‘Heart of Hops’ premises to trade until am at a weekend.One neighbour, who stays just metres away from the bar’s outside seating area, says: “We feel that the opening hours till am are unacceptable due to noise which will carry to our home.“We were under the impression that closing time would be the normal pm.”Another questions how the outdoor area will be effectively managed to avoid neighbourhood disturbance.Licensing standards officers have recommended restricted use of the outdoor area and that it should not be used until noon daily and close by pm Sunday to Thursday and pm on a Friday and Saturday.After a - vote back in April, the licensing board narrowly paved the way for the pub’s opening last month despite BrewDog not possessing a provisional licence.It took the highly unusual step of granting two occasional licences to enable it to trade from the former Mitchell’s Dairy premises on Market Street.BrewDog retail director James Brown told the board the firm had made “a huge commitment to Inverurie and Aberdeenshire” and afterwards said he was “delighted” with the decision.Audrey Junner of agents Hill Brown Licensing, stressed at the time that BrewDog had no intention to trade by way of occasional licences for an extended period of time.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: oldmeldrum start up doubles team
story: An Oldmeldrum-based business which provides customs and supply chain support has doubled its team since the start of the year with a number of key appointments.Bethan Customs Consultancy has appointed former HMRC Higher Office George Laing to the role of Customs Consultant, where he joins fellow consultant and former HMRC colleague, Elaine Lownds and the firm’s director, Nicola Alexander.Since January of this year, the team has doubled from three members of staff to six.George’s addition to the team creates new opportunities for Bethan to meet the increasing demand for its bespoke and independent service offerings, as well as to expand its capacity for dedicated in-house and remote customs consultancy to clients.Before taking up his role with Bethan, George enjoyed a very distinguished -year career within the civil service. He has held a number of roles within the Inland Revenue and HMRC in both Glasgow and the North East. Most recently he worked as a Higher Officer in Customs International Trade, where he specialised in Authorised Economic Operatorapproval processes.Director and founder of Bethan Customs Consultancy, Nicola Alexander, said: “George’s appointment comes at a very exciting time for Bethan, and we are absolutely thrilled to welcome him on board.“With his experience and knowledge of customs compliance, I have no doubt he will be yet another asset in our team of consultants, all of whom apply their expertise in customs, logistics and supply chain management to help our clients grow their businesses.”George added: “I am looking forward to building on my previous experience in my new role with Bethan.“I see this as a natural progression from my previous role within HMRC – guiding and supporting clients to navigate the complexities of importation and exportation from a customs perspective, particularly during these unprecedented times.”The firm offers a bespoke service, tailored to their clients’ business requirements, which span a range of sectors, from oil and gas to food and drink.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. title: new partnership for orkneys world heritage site
story: An ambitious new partnership to shape the future direction for Orkney’s World Heritage Site was unveiled today, Tuesday.The partnership brings together Historic Environment Scotland, Orkney Islands Council and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, who have signed a Memorandum of Understandingto conserve the Heart of Neolithic Orkney site and enhance the visitor experience for tourists and local people.The first phase will see an initial investment of over £, at the Standing Stones of Stenness to upgrade car parking facilities and improve the pathways network to encourage greater connection between monuments and surrounding areas.Funding will also be invested into looking at the visitor journey and exploring opportunities for greater connectivity and enhancement of how visitors experience over , years of history.The signing and first phase of the project follows an initial scoping exercise to look at current challenges and opportunities facing the World Heritage Site, within the context of Orkney’s wider heritage and tourism offer, particularly how to manage the growing number of visitors drawn to the site by its internationally famous monuments.Designed to work alongside the existing World Heritage Site Management Plan, the Partnership, in consultation with industry and other stakeholder will look at areas including visitor flow management, infrastructure and connectivity.The project will also see further investment in the island’s visitor offer to create a destination-led approach, whilst championing opportunities for sustainable tourism.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney folk urged to adopt a beach for 2019 clean up
story: The Marine Conservation Societyis appealing for people in Orkney adopt a local beach and lead a clean-up and survey during this year#s Great British Beach Clean.This year#s beach clean will run from September  to .The MCS says last year#s beach cleans saw volunteers pick up over  items of litter for every m of UK coastline surveyed. Just short of , volunteers took part — double the number in .“Cleaning so many inidual beaches last year was a fabulous achievement by our volunteer cleaners and organisers,# said Lizzie Prior, MCS Beachwatch Officer.#But we know that it#s only the tip of the iceberg. There are hundreds and hundreds of beaches around our coasts that have never been cleaned and surveyed — and it#s the collection of this data that is so important to getting even more positive actions implemented than have already been achieved in the last year or so.##This year we’re appealing for more people to adopt a beach and become one of our army of beach clean organisers.”“It’s an absolutely vital role because the more beaches we have litter data for, the clearer the picture we will have of where it all comes from and what needs to be targeted next.”Anyone interested in becoming involved with this year#s Great British Beach Clean simply has to find a beach they want to clean, sign up and register it on the MCS online system and MCS will provide them with all the help they need to get going.“We hope to have even more people cleaning up Britain#s beaches this September than we did last year, so registering your events with us soon is invaluable,” added Lizzie Prior.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
